title: Communication Methods & Channels
description: Master the communication channels formula and select the right technology for distributed teams.
objectives: Calculate communication channels using n(n-1)/2 formula
Select appropriate communication technology for co-located vs distributed teams
Recognize and mitigate communication barriers (language, culture, technical)
Apply Rich vs Lean communication based on message complexity

screens.headline: 5 People → 10 People. Channels Tripled. Productivity FELL 20%.

dialogue.text: More people = faster delivery, right? I hired 5 more to speed things up!

screens.learningHook: Every new person adds (n-1) new channels. 10 people = 45 channels. That's coordination tax, not productivity. Brooks's Law: Adding people to late projects makes them later.

screens.title: Communication Channel Optimization
screens.instructions: Solve 4 communication challenges facing the distributed expansion team.

questions.question: How many channels now with 10 members? What's the % increase?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Formula n(n-1)/2: 10(9)/2 = 45 channels. 350% increase explains the productivity drop—more coordinating, less executing.
feedback.incorrect: Use formula n(n-1)/2. With 10 members: 10(9)/2 = 45 channels. That's 350% more than the original 10 channels.

questions.question: Match each communication need to the right approach:

feedback.correct: Excellent! Async for routine (respects time zones), Sync for urgent (finds overlap), Sync rotating for strategic.
feedback.incorrect: Daily updates work async. Urgent decisions need sync at overlap times. Strategic planning needs sync with rotating times.

scenarios.title: Communication Barriers
description: Yuki (Japan): Limited English, misunderstands technical emails
Mexico: Unreliable internet, video calls drop

questions.question: Match each barrier to its mitigation:

feedback.correct: Perfect! PM ADAPTS to barriers. Visual aids for language, cultural learning, async workarounds for technical issues.
feedback.incorrect: PM adapts to barriers—don't demand stakeholders change. Use visual aids, learn cultural patterns, work around technical constraints.

scenarios.title: Rich vs Lean Communication
description: Choose high-bandwidth (video, in-person) vs low-bandwidth (email, text) for each need

questions.question: Match each need to Rich or Lean communication:

feedback.correct: Excellent! Rich for complexity/emotion/nuance. Lean for routine/documentation.
feedback.incorrect: Use Rich communication for complex topics and conflict. Lean for routine updates and documentation.

content.formula: n(n-1)/2 where n = number of stakeholders
content.insight: Adding people creates EXPONENTIAL communication overhead, not linear productivity gains.
content.brooksLaw: Adding manpower to a late project makes it later.

synchronous.useWhen: Urgent decisions, complex discussions, relationship building

asynchronous.useWhen: Routine updates, time zone challenges, documentation

content.bestPractice: Distributed teams: async for routine, sync for critical

barriers.mitigation: Simple language, visual aids, confirm understanding
Async primary, phone backup, lowest-common-denominator tools
Find overlap times, rotate meeting burden
Active listening, seek to understand first

rich.characteristics: Immediate feedback, visual cues, tone of voice
rich.useFor: Complex topics, conflict, relationship building, ambiguity

content.selectionCriteria: Complexity high = Rich. Urgency high = Rich. Relationship new = Rich. Routine = Lean.

correct.text: I thought more people = faster. 45 channels explain why standups took 30 minutes and productivity fell. It's coordination tax, not progress.
Async for routine respects time zones. Sync for urgent finds overlap. Sync rotating for strategic shares the burden. That's distributed team best practice.
I can't change Yuki's English or Mexico's internet overnight. But I CAN adapt my communication approach—visual aids, cultural learning, async workarounds.
Email for status, video for architecture, in-person for conflict. Match bandwidth to message complexity.

screens.title: Toronto Expansion Communication Plan
screens.context: Plan communication for Toronto expansion: 8 members across 4 time zones.

scenario.title: Toronto Team Communication
details: 8 members: Alex, 3 local, 2 SF support, 1 India vendor, 1 London consultant
Time zones: Toronto (EST), SF (-3), India (+10.5), London (+5)

questions.question: How many communication channels with 8 members?
Daily standup with 16-hour time span—best approach?

options.text: Synchronous daily call at fixed time

feedback.correct: Correct! 16-hour span makes daily sync impossible. Async written standup respects all time zones.
feedback.incorrect: With 16-hour time span, daily sync is unreasonable. Use async written standup.

questions.question: Complex vendor contract negotiation with India—Rich or Lean?

options.text: Rich (video call despite time zone challenge)

feedback.correct: Correct! Complex legal terms need real-time Q&A. Schedule video call at overlap time despite inconvenience.
feedback.incorrect: Complex contract negotiation needs Rich communication—video call for real-time Q&A and clarification.

screens.title: Communication Mastery
screens.summary: Communication channels grow exponentially. Select sync/async based on urgency, adapt to barriers, match rich/lean to complexity.
takeaways: Channels formula: n(n-1)/2 — exponential growth, not linear
Brooks's Law: Adding people increases coordination overhead
PM adapts to barriers (visual aids, cultural learning, tech workarounds)
Rich = complexity, conflict. Lean = routine, documentation

characterClosing.text: I added people thinking it would speed things up. Now I understand—more people = more coordination overhead. Work smarter with communication, not just harder with headcount.
